I played this game for 16 hours because I really wanted to enjoy it.
First of all, I wanted to like it because I'm a fan of first 3 parts of Gothic. Let's say it straight, this is different game, don't expect fourth part of Gothic. Some elements are similar, but general feeling is: this is different game.
So in the next step I tried to enjoy it as RPG game. If game is different than Gothic, that doesn't mean it's a bad game, right? So in that situation it is not true. This game is bad. Some elements, like graphics and music are quite nice, but generally game is just bad. Main story is totally linear, you can't go wherever you want. World is divided to small parts and you have to explore them one by one, you can't encounter a lot stronger monsters than you.
I love RPGs, but this game didn't sucked me. I didn't feel that I explore the world I want to explore. I didn't feel I'm a part of adventure, I want to be part of.

VERDICT:
If you're a fan of Piranha Bytes games, save yourself the disappointment.
If you're a fan of good RPG games, there are many better games out there.
If you finished all RPGs and you need to play it, be prepared to collecting the honey in one of most stupid quests. So if you like winnie the Pooh, go ahead, this game is made for you.

Hello. Are you interested in buying this game ? Let me tell you about this game. This game is not worth your time and money. This game starts you off as a shepherd (not THE shepherd) and has you trying to woo your girlfriend on some island. This game will then do what any game does to ruin the good mood and send you away on a journey for revenge.
All the story progress in this game is just for the sake of getting your revenge. Remember that, when you slug through the chapters, hoping for a cool story.

This game lets you decide on how to play it by offering you all the options : Melee, Ranged and Magic. The overly simplistic and lame skill-tree requires tough decision making from you. +1% mana and +1% mana regen or rather +1% stamina and +1% stamina regen...or maybe +1% ranged damage and +1% mana regen ? The choices...Eventually you might also reach one of the maybe 10 new skills..I say new, but in the end they just change the skill you already have to something better, like giving you a power bash or letting you combo more attacks...meh.

This game is kinda separated into different hubs, where the actual chapter is being played. As soon as you finish one, you basically move onward to the next hub area. This game is technically an open world game, but you don't have any necessity to ever venture back to the places you've already been to and instead keep following a linear route to your goal. This game sports acceptable environmental graphics, but butt-ugly character models. This game also features some of the most laid back casual combat ever. This game is hardly a challenge on normal difficulty and at least your progress will be steady..combat wise..

This game however does have a major flaw, which will most likely make you quit rather sooner than later :
THIS GAME HAS NO QUEST MARKERS. This game will just tell you to find an item/person in the east/west/north/south of where you accept the quest and then has you run around the place trying to find the item/person without any sort of indication. Even worse, this game often has the habit of only spawning the item/person you are looking for once you accepted the quest to do so. I just finished this game...including nearly all sidequests. I really wanted to like this, but I just can't. The problem is not, that this is not Gothic anymore. I knew that already when I bought it (Even thou it tries to be Gothic by having the name in its title). The Problem is, even seeing it as a single game, without the series, its just not a good game. However I'll try to make a list of pros and cons here and you'll see for yourself if you want to play it or not:

Pros:
-Graphics + Design of the enviroment
-Easy controls
-Very easy, its pretty hard to die in the beginning, it slowly gets harder, but you never get to the point where you need more than 2-3 tries to kill an enemie, which makes it a good game for people, who don't often play RPG's and/or want quick and fast progress
-It's not hard to find your way, they're all pretty obvious, there are no long walking parts
-You meet some NPC's from the Gothic games (however meeting some of them makes no sense, because of the end of Gothic 3)
-(Bandages are food ;b)

Cons:
-Voice actors in german and english (didn't try others) are terrible. You just can't take them seriously
-The only thing you need gold for is potions, weapons/armor are free, which gives you nearly no reason to explore your enviroment -> if you do so, you'll find nothing better anyways
-There are no real choices and the few choices you make have no influence
-Combat is pretty much clicking, clicking, clicking...and rolling now and then
-The story is linear, you visit one part of your map after the other, there is no need to go back and what happens next is obvious all the time, every possible cliché is used
-Skill tree...is not a tree, more like skill lines, good thing is you can't do anything wrong here and your skills don't have influence on what weapons/armor you wear. Magic skill lines will upgrade your spell, there are only 3 spells in total for the whole game
-Lots of quest items only spawn after you got the quest...one more reason to not look into caves as long as noone tells you to do so
-The graphics are good in general, but you'll find lots of glitches/textures
-Invisible walls everywhere
-No reason to play it again, you'll see everything there is in one playthrough
-Some small bugs (NPC's not willing to talk to you unless you reload your last save, enemies getting stuck)

reviewText:
When you play ArcaniA aka Gothic 4, it seems to be very important how the game is compared to it's predecessors. And there's a lot to live up to because the first 2 games were considered sort of icons of the genre. Here’s a list of remarks made while playing:

Game mechanics:
+ Looting is fast and simple.
+ One of the coolest looking minimaps I've seen.
+ Main quest conversations trigger automatically when approaching the right npc. This prevents fruitless dialogues with npc's who don't really have anything to say.
+ Health regenerates
+ Interesting lock picking system
+ Game creates savegames itself in important places. Don't remember the previous ones doing that.
- If the quest location stays out of the range of the minimap then the minimap doesn't show you the direction towards the location.
- Minor bugs with characters getting stuck behind invisible obstacles.
- The question weather it is open world or not. Fans of Gothic say that ArcaniA is not open world like the other Gothic games were. I ask: was Gothic 1 open world? They say 'yes, but a really small open world'. I say: well, there you have it. Arcania has those small areas, bigger than in Witcher, but it's not open in the same way Gothic 3, Skyrim and GTA were. I bring it up because it has been noted as a flaw.
- Levelling up badly balanced. The game is way too generous in helping you max your stats. By the time I was through two thirds of the game I had maxed out everything I needed.

Design:
+ Beautiful textures, highly improved compared to Gothic 3 BUT they blend together horribly.
+ Weirdly the game get's better designwise as the it advances. Looks like they created the first chapter just to learn how to do the job.
- The guy who created the 3D models didn't have a clue about human anatomy.
- Like so often in games the main character looks like some fancy-pants out of a men's magazine.
- In game written material is in some kind of modern comic font which doesn’t blend with the rest of the game at all.
- During dialogues, when the characters are zoomed in, armor stretches and bends as if it was part of flesh and muscle.
- Insanely few character models. The orcs, for example, look all the same.

Game flow:
+ ArcaniA’s best feature: they've come up with a helpful, easy-to-use dodging system. My experience with other games (Elder Scrolls, Assassin's Creed, Gothic) is that going in for the kill is more profitable that starting to dodge/ block, which in most cases is hard and pointless. ArcaniA nailed it and I give them huge credit for it.
+ Npc's with quests are marked with an exclamation mark.
+ Auto-aim enemies in malee battle (like in Assassin’s Creed) . In ArcaniA you come across places where you fight off 8 enemies or so at once. The auto trigger feature makes the battle in such occasions more fluent and faster overall.

Atmosphere:
+ The protagonist actually talks when you trigger a dialogue. Games these days (Skyrim, Half-Life etc.) have taken the silent protagonist approach which in my opinion closes some potent doors.
+ Diego and Gorn are the coolest they've ever been during the whole series.
+ The character is a charming fellow with good spirit. It contrasts highly with the previous nameless hero who at least in Gothic 3: Forsaken Gods was a war mongering bloody dictator who went after some small tribes that wanted to live their own way).
+ Goblins do whatever goblins might do before you arrive, they don't just stand there idly. They have a tribal look and seem a little more sophisticated than those poor bare guys in Gothic 3. AND they carry cool names like ''Warrior of the bugeater tribe'.
+ There's actually an epic story behind the whole thing with twists and drama.
- To the end it doesn't develop that true Gothic atmosphere that made the previous games popular.
- Voice acting is terribly overdramatized, doesn't sound like natural speech at all.
- In the whole there's not much to explore, the world feels empty.

A remark about Gothic: some ancient cultures belived that your spirit is immune to harm if your enemy didn't know your real name. The idea is used in both fantasy books and occult rituals. You have to know the name of the demon to summon him. Knowing the name bends the demon to your will. This allegory now comes to mind as I think of the former nameless hero, now Rhobar III who has been attacked by a demon. While he was nameless, he was mighty, but once he got a name, he became subject to harm. The game unconciously plays with this idea.

The verdict:

Try the game. Never mind the old Gothic games, they had their flaws as well. Arcania had both good and bad sides.

I have never played a game before in the Gothica series, so in regards to the reviews towards the game's story and depth I did not hold much creed in.  Because I had no basis of comparison from this series specifically, I dismissed those criticisms as associative and wanted to play the game on it's own merits.

Graphically, this game is quite impressive for a title from it's time.  The bitmaps, many of the object models, and foliage and water all look impressive and would be comparable to a game from today.  Environmental sounds are also quite good.  Character models however are showing their age; all males and females share the same basic physique, and the character model used is pretty simplistic.  The player character looks like he's got a bird's nest growing on his scalp.  His hair is detailed but does not move; the hair spray in the Gothica universe must use super glue as it's base.

The writing and voice acting in this game are jarringly bad and repeatedly wreck the process of immersion.  For example, at the beginning of the game, you need to acquire a bangle so that you can propose to your girlfriend.  Despite just previously completing a quest that had me wipe out a camp of goblins (thus having gold from corpses and weapons to sell going into this quest), here I see my character rationalizing having to do a retrieval quest for the bangle because he 'has no gold', which was clearly and obviously incorrect.

The dialogue 'tree' in this game is flat-out nonsense.  You rarely have any actual options, and after a couple of hours, I stopped caring about what lore they may reveal and just wanted to move on to questing.  A couple of hours after that, I no longer wanted to play.

Despite the fact that this game was also made for consoles, this version does not have a functioning inventory while using the controller.  I found this to be an unacceptable technical oversight when compiled with the other problems I had playing this game.

I can't recommend a game that I have no desire to finish.  I don't know how this game compares to other games in the Gothica series, but I generally don't think this is even a good RPG.

-Decent Story, and good story flow.
-Enviroments are pretty big
-Good weapons
-Good Armour
-Good crafting, and was easy to make money.
-Worth playing if you buy it for 75% off or more.  It's not worth more money than that.
-Has a Demo you can download on Steam.  Try before you buy!

CONS

-Fast travel is terrible, and feels unfinished.  You get two portals to travel within each town, so you can fast travel within a town but you can't fast travel to a far away town.  You pretty much have to run from portal to portal.  Simply it's only half as good as the fast travel of Oblivion or Risen.
-The ONLY way you can sprint is with the Runes or Potion to run fast.  Runes have cool down, and potion ingredients are limited.  A real pain when there isn't a great fast travel built into the game. You get a little bored with the slow traveling, and discouraged me from backtracking to find all the statues etc for the bonus items.
-Dialog is really bad! Not the writing, but the mismatched inflections in the conversation.  Most of the time the hero comes off as a jerk.  It's like they recorded the actor saying one sentence then copied and pasted it into every conversation whether the tone matched the conversation or not.
-The mission tracking on the map is only good half the time.  The other half you'll be googling to figure out where the heck your mission is located.
-Graphics aren't great, espcially sky lines and shorelines.
-Trader menu for crafting scrolls doesn't tell you whether you own it or not. Also you can't compare item stats you have equipped to items in trader menu.
-Women are not painted in a very good light. After playing through Arcania then Fall of Setarrif right after, I was wondering if there were women haters who worked on this game... The women are painted as stuck up b*tches, or ♥♥♥♥♥s.
-The PS3 version had Trophies, it would have been nice if it had Steam achievements.

reviewText:
This game lacks pretty much everything that makes Gothic 2 or even Risen (the real successor to the Gothic games) special.

The atmosphere in Gothic was always the highlight for me. That feeling of being new to a world full of different factions and people who all have their own schedules and agendas and belongings and character. Arcania only brings gated zones that you unlock as the story progresses and characters who are bland. Most of the people in this game don't even own or have ownership over anything, or say anything meaningful or at all when you try to talk to them.

In past games going into someone's house or stealing their belongings would get you in trouble. In this game citizens will go about their day as you pilfer their chests. Another thing that really struck me was that I was able to fight 3 wild animals in the middle of a crowded tavern and not a single character reacted in any way to what was happening. In Gothic 2 or Risen, the NPCs react to creatures, and will actually fight them. Sometimes they die and are dead permenantly! In Arcania I tried to fight a bandit who was blocking a region I needed to get into, and my attacks did nothing to him as he stood there oblivious to my efforts to kill him. It comes off feeling lifeless and empty compared to previous Gothic games.

While passable as a RPG, this game does nothing to live up to the tacked on 'Gothic' name. For fans of the series this game holds practically nothing for you and I do not recommend. For newcomers you are better served playing Gothic 2 or Risen.

reviewText:
Graphics:
+ The graphics were decent for a game that was released in 2010. There are quite a lot of details on characters. The areas look pretty neat as well.

- Many characters are clones and animations could be smoother here and there.

Sound:
+ The music is good overall but really not as amazing as it was in past Gothic games. The voice acting in the English version is completely horrible and makes you cringe at times. Stream should allow players to decide themselves which sound packs to install. The german voice acting is much better.

- The environment does not make too much sound. You would expect to hear animals and other things.

Balance:
+ You can clearly feel that your character is developing and there are 4 difficulties.

- The 4 difficulties are meaningless. Having played the game on 'Gothic' which is supposed to be the hardest difficulty I have never felt like the game was hard. I have never died a lot except for the last boss which was the first time I started using pots and buffs. Funnily enough I only died 3 times on the last boss which isn't even a lot.

Atmosphere:
+ Many dialogues are neat if it wasn't for the horrible voice acting. You can feel part of the world. You keep meeting characters you met before and NPCs seem to be moving with you. You also meet old characters from past Gothic games which is a big plus for fans of the franchise.

- The world is very stale and boring. There is nothing to explore except things that you are meant to explore. You can only quest in the area you are meant to quest. All areas are cut off and you can only progress once you do the required main quest. The atmosphere is long not as brilliant as in past Gothic games.

UI:
+ The UI is decent and I never had issues with controlling my character. You can put up to 10 items and spells on your bar which is more than enough. In addition you can bind the keys.

- The character gets 'stuck' pretty often when he shouldn't be. Sometimes he gets stuck while simply running which forces you to jump occasionally.

Content:
+ The game is somewhat long. It took me 40 hours to finish but that's including doing extremely boring quests which forces you to run through the entire world to look for hidden artifacts.

- Many areas have nothing special in them. Sometimes you run through a jungle area in which you do nothing at all except run. Why not put one quest where nearby orcs have stolen or killed a friend? Instead there are just random little camps with orcs which you clear and move on. A lot of potential was lost. There are also barely any side-quests at all.

Quests:
+ The questing is very bad in Arcania. There are nearly no side-quests. However the story starts off in an interesting way.

- Most quests are only about either killing a few monsters or bringing the NPC a few items. The quest stories are also very boring and even when you can do it in more than 1 way it has no effect on the story or even the rewards.

Charactersystem:
+ The charactersystem is decent. Most of the abilities are useful and you can specialize in things.

- However the system is very simple and boring. You barely have a choice in what to specialize in since there are so little abilities and you will learn all by the end.

Combatsystem:
+ The comatis fast and interactive. You have to dodge certain attacks which you cannot parry. Other attacks can be parried if you are fast enough.

- The AI is horrible. Many monsters simply keep hitting you with special attacks which force you to dodge. They also hit so slow that it is no challenge to get away from them before they hit you. There are also only 3 spells in the game which make being a Mage pretty boring.

Items:
+ There are many items and you can craft a lot of items yourself.

- The crafting is useless though. I played the entire game on the hardest difficulty and have never crafted a single pot. When the game was over my inventory was still filled with all kinds of materials. I only crafted around 3 items to wear. Many items were simply useless. You also get new armour very rarely when the game decides you should get a new armour.

Conclusion:
I have played Gothic and Gothic 2 in the past and was highly interested in Arcania. Sadly I found out that Jowood and Piranha Bytes had an argument which is which Jowood removed them and took the rights to the game themselves. They paid another developer team to work on Gothic 4 which is why the game is completely horrible compared to the other Gothic games. I would even say that they ruined the Gothic story. Even though you meet old friends you don't actually seem to work with them that much. The game turned into a drag half-way and I just honestly wanted to finish it which is why I did not even obtain the best armour available. Worst of all is that they end the story abrubtly. The DLC of the game is required to really understand the story. They obviously cut the game off before release just to sell the DLC of the rest.
I would only recommend this game to real hardcore RPG fans and fans of Gothic but not to anyone else.

reviewText:
I'll write this review for the sake of those who haven't followed the Gothic games.

See, long story short there was a divide between the old guard who liked Gothics 1 and 2, believing Gothic 3 was a poor sequel, and folks like me who agree that Gothics 1 and 2 were classic but 3 had a charm of its own. It's true, I enjoyed 3 and I still recommend it, even if I had some mechanical problems with its expansion (For the record I NEVER had any problem with the base game and although it could've used more content, I had a lot of fun exploring it!).

Now when Arcania (the de facto Gothic 4, under a new name for understandable reasons due to studio changes) was announced, the old guard of the former group were pessimistic and people like me were hopeful. I wanted a more polished game that offered the sort of open-world exploration, side quests laced through the main quest, secrets to find, factions to join or oppose and engaging choices that made the last games great, coupled with improved visuals and controls but especially more options and items and goodies in general.

What I got was an unbelievably linear, limited game that seemed to strip everything that made 3 fun while keeping everything the old guard criticized about it. I couldn't even finish it. I was bored out of my skull before I could even save the capital, let alone figure out what the nonsensical plot was about.

Maybe it's a little better if you aren't familiar with the previous games, but even then it's an unfortunate use of money to buy. You want to play Gothic, check out the previous three and leave this on the shelf. Fair warning though, I have trouble getting 1 and 2 to work on newer computers.

reviewText:
Not at all a legitimate part of the 'Gothic' series. Terrible story, awful narrative and devoid of any profound similarity or entertainment value had with the games developed by Piranha Bytes.

Takes all the charm and rewarding qualities that made 'Gothic' unique and turns it into a casual hack-and-slash.

The best example of how they screwed this game up is... In the other games you get skill points which you use with skill trainers to teach you how to be and do what you want. With magic, especially, it's difficult to acquire because you have to get accepted into the mage's guild/monastery before you learn how to use magic. So you're taught to save your skill points until you can become a mage, if that's the way you want to go. Making becoming a mage an actual ACHIEVEMENT and something difficult to pull off. But it's the most powerful class in the game(s) because the fireball ends up being able to one-hit-kill. It's an incredibly rewarding feeling.

In this game? At level 4 you can use magic. No skill trainers. Just a character screen and you click the little plus sign.

And magic is completely meaningless.

Without putting any points into any skills, you can be waving a massive sword around wiping out mobs like there's no tomorrow. Again, you originally needed to train to be able to use large weapons. Again, it was an achievement to get that.

It goes to show how some publishers (and new developers working with an old IP) don't comprehend what gave these games their dedicated fan-base

reviewText:
ArcaniA is the most enjoyable of all the Gothic titles in my opinion. It tries hard to fix a lot of the issues the old games had. There are a lot of options to make questing more straightforward, distances between questgivers and questtargets are of reasonable length and there have been attempts to make the narrative work. First impressions while playing were actually really good, having just finished Gothic II (and not enjoying it) before playing ArcaniA the change of pace really felt good, appearances of the characters from older games and a seemless integration of this title into the Gothic-timeline were a nice touch too. Halfway into it, it had been a really nice if somewhat shallow experience.

Unfortunately, after that point it suddenly becomes stale really quickly - I could not help but feel like they were running out of time/money in development during the final hours of the game, as the experience shifted from being fast and rewarding to tedious and slow, forcing backtracking and seemingly trying to hold the player back in order to lengthen the time you spend in the final areas of the game.

In the final hours of Arcania, it's major flaws become very obvious. Particularly dungeons are a definitive low-point, just endless caves or temple corridors filled with the same enemies over and over again. It's literally like Deja-Vu as you keep fighting through seemingly identical rooms again and again. Lacking enemy variety and a button-mashy combatsystem do not help the game and become a real problem in said dull dungeons. Loot and items are kinda broken, you find tons of trash loot and a few really good pieces but I ended up using one sword for the majority of the game because it was simply the best I could find. Same goes for armor, at certain points you get a complete set that is considerably better than the set you had before and that is pretty much it - sure, helmets and bracers as well as jewelry can be found, but they usually only raise your attributes and aren't all that interesting. I would have enjoyed a different approach here if they would only have went with the straightforward approach here as well - a few good items that maybe even have different properties and handle seriously different would have been much more appreciated by me than the tons of useless junk you collect along the way.

The roleplaying aspect is as lackluster as the rest, the skilltree" is kind of a joke (they might as well auto-level and not let me spend points in a bunch of categories that unlock a handful of "skills" of which 50% are passives). The game just lacks a sense of meaningfulness and depth (even smithing and Alchemy can't help that)

reviewText:
I am not a Gothic fan; I have not played previous games in the series.  I came to Arcania without expectations colored by the previous games.  I chose 'recommended' only because Arcania is not a terribly bad game.  It's a fairly mediocre RPG.  There are better games out there, no question.  But if you're in an RPG dry spell and you can get Arcania on sale, it's not a bad 40 or so hours.  It's also pretty stable, the only crash I had was after minimizing several times.

The graphics are fine for 2010.  The game lacks AA but the jaggies didn't really bother me here.  I did have problems with the horizon between the sky and sea blinking constantly, but I don't know if that's an original flaw in the game or it just isn't aging well with newer graphics cards and drivers.  For the most part the game looks pretty good.  The big exception is the human characters.  In dialogs the hair is frequently translucent and faces can look horrible.

For me, the strength of Arcania lies in its combat (melee at least, I didn't use bow and arrow much at all).  I chose to focus on melee and go sword & board.  The combat relies on flurries and power swings.  The flurry system is very similar to combat in The Witcher.  Combine that with dodge rolling to escape getting hit and you have a fairly engaging melee combat system.  I thought melee combat in Arcania was more engaging than in any Elder Scrolls game I've played  (even though, yes, every Elder Scroll game I've played is overall much, much better than Arcania).

The magic system is very simplistic - 3 types of magic (fire, frost, electric) with added features gained on leveling up the appropriate skill.  The magic system enhances the melee combat nicely: you can paralyze opponents with the electricity spell or slow them with the frost spell, before attacking them.  But it's nothing like the complexity in Two Worlds 2.

Crafting is a bit of a let down.  It's all done in a menu, no need to be at a bench or specific location.  I found weapon and armor crafting to be almost useless (except for the one quest specific crafting of a weapon).  Alchemy and cooking was more robust with a decent selection of potions and recipes to buff/heal your character in various ways.

The story is fairly standard - an unknown man (you cannot play as a female) saves the world.  The story starts off as a revenge tale, which would have been just fine, but by the end it morphs into a save the world cliché.  The game is pretty straight forward.  There is the main quest and various side quests.  There are no factions to join or advance in like in Elder Scroll games or Two Worlds (1 and 2).  Arcania is not open world like Oblivion or Skyrim.  Various sections of the world open up as you advance the main quest, similar to Two Worlds 2 or The Witcher.

I've played worse RPGs.  Arcania is stripped down and bare bones compared to something like Oblivion or The Witcher.  I had fun with it considering its limitations.  If I had to do it all over again, I would have waited to get Arcania on sale if I had a fantasy RPG itch that couldn't be scratched in any other way.  It definitely wasn't worth the $50 I paid back in 2010.  But given that I bought it, I don't think it was a total waste of my money.

reviewText:
This game lacks a lot. Gameplay is over-simplified, with only three spells for a caster and a very simple melee system. You can craft, cook and brew anywhere without using a workbench - hell, workbenches are in the game but don't have any use, even if you turn on 'Roleplaying elements' in the options. There is no penalty for stealing stuff, you can't beat up friendly NPCs. Although you're playing in one big world, the pathing is painfully linear. You can't walk down edges (unless you jump), and exploring usually kills you - like when you touch the water surface of a lake you thought you could swim through. The new main character doesn't keep up with the previous nameless hero (how could he anyway?), the story is dull, quests are repetitive and most characters are unconvincing.

Most. What made this game for me was really was the opportunity to meet old friends. Especially Diego and Gorn really shine in this game, and seeing Lester and Milten again also didn't hurt. Besides that, the game is stripped down and shifted way more from the hard old-school RPG to a casual Action RPG, which - if you let yourself in for it - has its benefits: the game is incredibly intuitive, you don't have to put a lot of time to learn the skill system or whatever, and combat feels wonderfully dynamic. The game also looks pretty nice.

I started the game on difficulty 'Gothic' (of course...) which is the hardest one they give you. If you come from Gothic, do this! After about 3/4 of the game I put it down to 'Hard' and then 'Normal' because it started to get difficult and enemies had riddiculously high HP, making combats last forever. This made the late game kinda chewy. It took me ~21 hours to finish the game, which isn't incredibly long for an RPG, but some hours less wouldn't have hurt.

I'll give it a 6.5 / 10, mostly for 'nostalgic value', nice graphics and overall a very polished and smooth experience. If (and only if) you are into the series, it's worth playing!

reviewText:
How would you like to see a combination between Fable [old school first game] and Elder Scrolls?
Gothic 4 - Arcania is pretty much the thin line that unites these 2 ideas.
I gotta say I have never had experienced the whole franchise before, only tried a bit of Gothic 3 after a friend told me about it [and wasn't bad at all].
Game was out around Oct 2010, which kinda made me expect a tinny bit better optimization regarding a few details than it had..



[Story]
The story is intriguing at start and in the end. Buuut after having played a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of games in my age, can't say I had my eyes popped. But it was cute.
A few side quests reveal a few more details to you and some fun points regarding what's going on.
I don't know if it is connected with the previous games but it stands alone not leaving me with major questions... Well.. except the final seconds of the cinematic at the end of the game, wasn't sure what I saw and what it meant. [*cough* probably leaving space for a sequel *cough*]
In average it's a cool story to be told, there's much drama script-wise which adds to the suspense but you can say that most of it gets pretty much expected after a point.
It's balanced, not too original.
Also RPG-wise it's ok, though they could add a few elements regarding romance or key characters to connect more with your character and not have just one super hero that kills and burns and stabs and slashes through everything just to see what's going on afterwards. I mean this isn't the 00s any more guys come on..

[Gameplay]
The gameplay is pretty linear but seeing it from an open minded point of view it didn't matter.
And I mean linear because you are indeed in an open world [and a pretty nice one actually] environment, but you cannot go everywhere you want unless you unlock the area through your main quests. Unfortunatelly you cannot climb mountains and you drawn the moment you step into water [facepalming a bit] so when you reach a bridge or a gate, you cannot pass it unless you get the key or some official letter to show to the guard in order to go pass it.
Lot's of quests to do, many RPG elements like tons of items, a crafting system, gathering materials from herbs, teeth and meat from animals to ores from mines.
Leveling system with a not too complicated [and actually maybe too simple] skills tree.
3 basic classes to go through, warrior, ranger, mage. Some nice animations to attack, block, evade etc.
Not really bad but then again too easily to be repetitive as hell and make you a bit bored after a long while.
Few bugs to notice, though my weak CPU cannot go without noticing some silly moments like snaps from frames that show my character in a model position [open arms and legs frozen half gear on] due to loading, or stupid unnnatural dialogue moments due to the way the data is loading..

[Graphics]
They are good for a 2010 game. Sweet open world filled with nature, forests, caves, dungeons, lakes, swamps, mountains etc..
People are nicely designed, though not really pretty faces. Maybe it's ok for being realistic, but sometimes I felt like I'd kill to see a pretty woman's face in there.
Armor and weapons are detailed and sweetly done, you can also have various effects with a few magical items.
Very nice weather system, animated nature depending how strong the winds are, rain with realistic sound and thunders and water that you can actually see the water dynamics even on your own armor [something not many games had achieved at that time].
Also has a night and day cycle, pretty neat when you see people going to sleep, then waking up to do their work or keep their shop.

[Music]
Very nice music. Pretty well done and balanced. Suits every moment in the game. I was surprised that I felt like going through some sort of Elder Scrolls game here and then.

[Sound]
I have to mention that sound is realistic. Not just due to good environmental effects, but for a 2010 game noticing a realistic difference of noice and sounds betwee being out in the wild and in a town, or between being ouside or inside a house is something worth appreciating.

[Characters]
I was not really satisfied by the characters in the game.
I mean, they are all done very nicely, designed and animated well. But there's just that one thing, that one element missing that never helped me to connect with any of them.
I never cared about whether my character was a nice guy or a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I never got sad over a few dramatic events that occurred during the game.
I wasn't even noticing the change of character and his evolution during the story until some points were made by the NPCs at some times.
This was a bit disappointing for me because connecting with my main character in a game is a major and very important thing when I play a game.
I cannot give you examples cause I don't wanna spoil anyone, but from time to time there had been a few major events happening that really left me standing with apathy in from of my screen wishing the dialogues were a bit shorter or even skipping them so that I could go on.

[Cast]
The voices are ok. Seen worse. Seen better.
Meeeeh. For a 2010 RPG open world mechanism they were ok.

[Others details]
The game had tons of exploring to do. If you are the explorer type you would enjoy going around gathering materials or collectibles.
Fun fact; nothing is randomly generated. Every flower you gather, every monster you kill, they are all unique and will never respawn again. That was quite realistic for me and loved the idea.
Also there were a few elements that reminded me of Fable. Starting of from a humble young man from a village, growing into a uber powerful super hero of muscle and awesomeness badassery and heavy metal while holding flaming swords and magic shields ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ass through the plot. \m/
[at some points you can see people acknowledging as a hero figure and their reactions are fun to hear]
Tons of RPG elements, but not quite developed. I mean they put so much efford in everything, they could at least add a few more ideas about spells or increase the max level cap and let you try other classes since there's no free roam mode after finishing the game.
Another thing; You all know me. I LOVE ROMACE in my stories. And this game had nothing at all except a small flirty idea at the intro of the game. I was like, come on is there anything to help me connect with this guy? Even the action sequence was completelly stable; explore, kill, talk to NPC, do quest, explore, kill, talk to NPC, do quest, explore....
One thing I liked, since everything in the game is not unlimited or randomly spawned, being an explorer is rewarding in many aspects. For example sometimes i would first completelly explore the whole new area I unlocked and if i was done I would talk to the NPCs. That way I already had the quest items they wanted and I would farm exp instantly.
Easy to get some extra skill points and make you happy for a while? Yes.
Does it make sense to already be able to distinguish a quest item from the rest of the world without having taken the quest thus making the item as useful to you as a random rock on the ground? No.
But i ain't even mad ¯\_(ツ)_/¯



[Average]
The game is pretty good.
It's hard to see through many points because there are imperfections to notice but let's not forget that the game is old.
If you are a hard core RPG fan do try it out. It's sweet and give food for thought regarding game elements and tastes.
If you are a person with high expectations and wants kickass high end video games. Do not buy.
The game is ok. A bit above average. I'd say around 7/10.

The main quest was very linear and besides some minor sidequests, you basically went in a line as you never revisited any other previous locations. The main quest itself got very disracted as at first, you're fighting for revenge (I am trying to avoid spoilers here!), and then you get distracted with trying to stop the paladins, and then you get distracted with trying to help the king, and then you get distracted by trying to save the city, etc. It felt like the quest was all over the place and when you finally accomplished one of the things, it was less than satisfactory. The sidequests themselves were mildly interesting. They actually rewarded pretty good loot and made them worth while.

It's listed as an RPG but the game isn't really one to be honest. Sure you can sort of focus on using swords or spells, but there are so few skills to upgrade, you end up getting all of them and it doesn't really matter what you're focusing on. The crafting system felt tacked onto the game as it doesn't really serve much of a purpose. I literally only used the health potions even though I could have made 30+ other potions. I also could have crafted some other weapons and armor but by the time I got the material required for them, I already had better weapons and armor than the thing I was trying to craft.

Some minor things I disliked about the game was that it seemed like there were only a few voice actors and there were only a few NPC models. There was basically no variation when meeting NPCs. Also it was annoying that I couldn't tell if I got hit by enemies. They would make a quick movement and I looked down at my health and saw they had somehow hit me.

The game itself was incredibly easy but I only played it on normal. After that, it can go up to hard and then gothic. I felt very overpowered and didn't really have to pay attention to my HP. I just pressed the attack button and rarely tried to dodge.

Some positive things about the game is that the bow mechanic was really cool. I also liked the overall lighting ambient in the game.  My favorite thing about the game however was probably that I was able to easily find better and better loot, from doing sidequests to doing the main quest. Normally games have a bunch of bad loot that you can get but this was a nice change.

As I said, overall 5.5/10.

There are a lot of flaws in this game compared to the other Gothic game but it's still a fun game if you get it cheap.
2 big flaws which are the same as the previous Gothic which are the freeroam and the ending.
Do not except  The Elder Scrolls or even a Fallout game, it's open world but at the same time it's linear.
You cannot continue after the ending, not even a new game plus.
There are many others unlike the other Gothic because this one is way too different from the previous ones
The game is even more linear than the previous ones.
ArcaniA doesn't always makes sense, that's for sure but it's still a fine game In my opinion.

If this game would have been more like the previous Gothic but with a better open world and a better ending then it would probably have been really great.

My favorite list:

1. Gothic II
2. Gothic
3. Risen
4. Gothic III
5. Risen 2: Dark Water
6. Arcania: Gothic 4 (I wouldn't consider this one as a Gothic game though)

They are all good In my opinion, but some are more worth than the others, of course, they all have their good and bad.
If only they would have a true freeroam and no ending.

6/10 (I'd suggest you get it while on sale, at least for 80% then it may be worth playing it a little).

reviewText:
NOT a strong recommendation! but I figure if your thinking about getting this game you'll do proper research before you spend your money on it. I got the whole Gothic series in a bundle on sale so I didn't pay anywhere near 20 USD for it, definitely not worth that much in my opinion. But worth something.

Ok RPG. (revised from AMAZING) I would recommend it because I had fun until I read people were hating on it then other people's opinions kind of changed my own. after reading the reviews i realized the game was very linear but before anyone told me it felt a lot like The Witcher 2. Still with that said I have never read reviews for The Witcher 2 but i seriously doubt people bash it as much as this game. Its not bad but it's no Elder Scrolls either. I have all the gothic games but haven't really played any other than this one simply because I buy way too many games and never have enough time to play them all before I have something new to play. So I'm not 'disappointed' by the deviation from the RPG elements of the earlier games. From my stand point I'm looking at it as a stand alone RPG not the 4th in a series.

The games graphics are amazing if your computer can handle running them at full blast, but some how the tone of the over-all game seems to be very empty. Partly due to the fact that the only fast travel is restricted to 2-way teleporting pads separated by long, LONG walks between areas.

The game doesn't really have any exploration value though so backtracking to old areas is almost nill. once you've completed an areas quest and unlocked the next area you will have little to no reason to return.

The game play mechanics were great at first, but that's bearing in mind that I have only played shooters on the PC and this was the first real RPG that I played. they are simple and fun enough, but annoying later on when you just dodge and hack enemies up over and over.

Loot, there's not much to speak of. more than anything you'll be carrying a bunch of junk around with you most of the time waiting to sell it. The magic they tried to incorporate into the game seems unfinished to me, mostly useless. Except one that makes you run faster for a short duration which is nice but annoying at the same time for having to walk such arduous distances in the first place.

reviewText:
+Good Visuals (Lighting, Post-Process, Effects)
+Great World/Level Design
+Good Loot System
+Combat is fun

-Inconsistent Visuals (No native Vsync, Disappearing Vegetation, Artifacts)
-Easy Game (Put difficulty to Hard/Gothic)
-One Playthrough Is Enough
-Average Story and Voice Acting

This game is not accurately described by its Metacritic score, however, the developers/publisher did not do themselves a favor in purporting the game as part of the Gothic franchise.  While the story is technically more interesting and coherent than previous Gothic games, the style of gameplay is significantly different as the design is aimed towards focused progression from point A to B.  The world is technically open, but there is never a reason to backtrack.  This design is not bad, however, as the developers make each step compelling enough with beautifully detailed locales and creatures to keep your interest.  If a fan of previous Gothics, understand that the structure is significantly different.  There are only a couple of decision points and there isn't a faction system to limit your abilities.  Abilities are also acquired via a skill tree rather than being trained and purchased from masters.  Still, this is a fun Action RPG and is worth a purchase when on sale.

I think I'm ready to recommend it. That's a nice action RPG, rather friendly to the player: it's easy to learn, intuitive enough, and it takes quite a lot of effort to die here - at least, as far as the beginning of it is concerned. I've played 12 hours so far, and I died only twice (more out of curiosity, in fact, than because of real failure).

I like games with strong lengthy storylines, and that's one of such cases. You can take a variety of side quests as well, but you always feel that it's just a pleasant addition for you to entertain yourself while doing the main quest, the Gothic Story. I have also appreciated the scrupulous approach to environment modelling that my favourite TES games lack sometimes: for example, when it's raining, the ground becomes wet, and people around you start to seek shelter.

What I really disliked was the fact that all NPCs have the same faces. Well, not all of them, but approximately 80-90% of people I met do. It seems that the developers have designed two or, maybe, three faces and decided that it's enough. In addition, women's faces are either unpleasant or plain ugly, and it really strikes you when someone supposed to be a nice young lady has a face of mature woman in her late fourties.

After approximately 10 hours of gameplay, I got the distinct impression that very little (if any) balancing or play testing went into this game.  I did finish this game before reviewing it, to give a complete impression.  I have never played the original Gothic games, so my I have no input on how close it is to the originals.

I will start with what I felt was wrong.  One, because if your reading this review, that is likely all you care about.  Two, because I believe on closing on a good note.

Cons:
1. The run speed!  Oh my god it is way too slow, and they made the horrible decision of throttling the speed even more when inside.  This made completing the game feel like a Sisyphean task.
2. Invisible walls and impassible gentle slopes.  It is a major pet peeve to have apparently impassible terrain made impassible.
3. Skill tree balancing.  It is not.  Melee is the best, and that’s good because that is what you will mostly find upgrades for.  Archery can be good, but upgrades are sparse.  Magic is a joke.  Even at max level magic is mostly just a support for melee. The skills feel like they are less balanced against each other, and more like they should all compliment each other at max level. reviewText:
A relaxed take on the Gothic universe that turns elements of previous gothic games into optional roleplay and provides a more frictionless hack'n slash combat style.  The handful of runes in the game are for sprinting or combat utility which continues the trend of runes taking a lesser role in recent Gothic games.

The island, story and situation you experience for the first 4 levels or so came off as corny, but the tone is a bit more serious and acceptable after leaving.  From then on the quests drive the story and character leveling at a satisfying pace which keeps you going through the linear progression with pockets of open exploration.  Though the story is not disinteresting, it doesn't manage to cultivate any emotional investment.

Very smooth enjoyable ride with beautiful environments lush with plant life, dynamic lighting, wind causing whole trees to sway, impressive grass render distance, a high frequency of stormy weather and some excellent fire particle effects.

It will not meet rigid expectations of what a Gothic game should be and this will be far from the highest production value RPG you've ever seen, but if you are craving a somewhat relaxing RPG with a bit less depth for a change then you might enjoy it as I have.  Hard difficulty is probably the sweet spot, as Normal is too easy and Gothic difficulty is considered by many to be unsatisfying.

First off: Never played any other game in the Gothic series, and everyone says this is far from Gothic 4 so lets assume it isn't.

ArcaniA, as an RPG is not bad.  The story moves along and it occasionally runs into speed bumps in the storytelling but otherwise for an almost 5 year old game it doesn't look or play badly.

My biggest gripe is that the game seems to be designed for strictly melee combat. You can certainly get spells and upgrade them and use a bow more if you feel thats your thing but from experience if you go down any other road than a typical barbarian build you're going to find difficulties. For instance, theres a skill tree for stealth but it doesn't give you a bonus for a stealth attack until you've accumulated a lot of skill points which you don't get a lot of per level.
You can certianly build a mage if you prefer but the game is pretty clear in it's limitations in regards to how you build the character.

Otherwise, the game is fun. The characters are interesting but more or less pretty standard characters for a fantasy game.

If you're looking for an inexpensive RPG that will hold your attention, ArcaniA should do nicely.
If you're expecting a Skyrim-esque experience, this is not it.

One thing I liked was the collectibles. In most games, they do nothing but reward you with some sort of achievement or otherwise forgettable reward. In this game, it clearly tells you what the rewards are and they could help your character depending on how you play. but at least you know ahead of time rather than finding out collecting all those items wasn't going to be worth it.

Its good. Get it.

reviewText:
For a game that got mixed reviews, I'm on the side of the more positive. As a fan of the older Gothic games, I was glad to see another Gothic game come around. After playing both XBox and PC versions of this game, hands down the PC version is the best. Not because of the better graphics, but the menus as well. On the console, the menus were kind of a pain to use and not thought out very well, whereas the PC version had easy to use menus. The game just felt as if it was designed to be played on the PC rather than a console.

One thing that striked me as odd was the disapearing foliage. I understand something like that if there's no machine that can handle playing it, but why have this in a game at all? It really felt out of place, AND a menu option didn't show up for it until I messed with the game settings saved on my hard drive....just odd..

The overall story was very good, but lacked substance. Not because it was a bad story, but because the game didn't do a very good job of explaining it to you. I had to play through the game to completion before I could get an overview of the story and why you do what you do. Still, I don't understand half of it, and had to actually read about it.

The gameplay is by far the most outstanding portion of this title. I really enjoy the combat in this game as it just feels more free than your standard hotkey RPG like most MMOs. Hotkeys are present, but their more for selecting weapons and skills rather than combat.

Overall, I give a 7.5/10. If you're a hardcore RPG fan and a fan of the older Gothic games, I recommend picking up this title. It's worth the $20.

reviewText:
A relaxed take on the Gothic universe that turns elements of previous gothic games into optional roleplay and provides a more frictionless hack'n slash combat style.  The handful of runes in the game are for sprinting or combat utility which continues the trend of runes taking a lesser role in recent Gothic games.

The island, story and situation you experience for the first 4 levels or so came off as corny, but the tone is a bit more serious and acceptable after leaving.  From then on the quests drive the story and character leveling at a satisfying pace which keeps you going through the linear progression with pockets of open exploration.  Though the story is not disinteresting, it doesn't manage to cultivate any emotional investment.

Very smooth enjoyable ride with beautiful environments lush with plant life, dynamic lighting, wind causing whole trees to sway, impressive grass render distance, a high frequency of stormy weather and some excellent fire particle effects.

It will not meet rigid expectations of what a Gothic game should be and this will be far from the highest production value RPG you've ever seen, but if you are craving a somewhat relaxing RPG with a bit less depth for a change then you might enjoy it as I have.  Hard difficulty is probably the sweet spot, as Normal is too easy and Gothic difficulty is considered by many to be unsatisfying.

Well, I don't really see where some of these bad reviews come from. I'll admit I'm only 16 hours into this game, However, I've been thoroughly enjoying this game. Visually, It's quite fun to look at it, Extremely beautiful. However there's a lot of reused sprites, and voices which can be a flaw to some (It is slightly annoying, but not a minus for me) I actually enjoy the story so far, I think the combat is alright with really three main ways of playing, Mage, Melee weapon or Bows/Crossbows. There's a lot of crafting you can do(Like making weapons) and a bit of alchemy to do(Like making your own potions, These potions vary from adding to your health regen to increasing your overall stats temporarily)

I will say this though, This game is a bit buggy. You can get stuck in poorly rendered areas or just jumping where you aren't suppose to go, The cut-scenes will make you crash from time to time as well, However you can easily watch the cut scenes from within the Arcania folder if you do crash and just skip them in game. Does this make the game unplayable? For me, No it doesn't. It can be annoying to crash during a cutscene and have to rewatch it again, But it's no big deal for the most part.

I'll also say this, I had a lot more problems running this game off an FX-8150 CPU than I do with my current i7 3770k(Graphics card is a 7970 for those wondering), Whether this game doesn't like AMD or something along those lines I can't say for sure, But my system isn't a slouch by any means. I feel like this game might run better on older systems then newer systems, For instance my laptop running an old first gen i7 at 1.73GHz and a 1GB ATI card(I think 5850) seems to run it without any cut scene errors or crashes.

But in the end, I really do enjoy this game, The main story keeps me interested, I feel the combat is alright for the style of game that it is, and despite some minor things here and there, I would recommend this game when it's on sale. reviewText:
Moderately Acceptable Spin-off

At first, you can't tell if this is a direct successor of the Gothic games, because some things point to that (the intro cinematic) or if it's something else completely, as other things go against everything that the Gothic series was known for (the gameplay, the skill progression).

Then you realise that it grows on you, like a scratchy beard that eventually becomes the second most played with part of your body. You see or hear about important characters that were present in each Gothic game so far and there are iconic monsters to fight with as well (damned scavangers!). You see a lot of bugs, so that helps too. You get used to the fact that everything is so much easier to do:
- Fighting and low HP? Just press your hotkey for the Health Potion and your combat isn't stopped; hell, sometimes you don't even see the character's animation for drinking, but at least you don't get killed by a freakin' wolf pack anymore!
- Reaching a new level and need to get new skills? Just bring up the Skills menu and bask in the glory of adding those 3 new learning points wherever you wish, even while fighting! Who cares how you suddenly learned how to cast a fireball after you finished off a scavanger and the rest of his pack is now chasing you?
- Learned how to brew a new potion or how to craft a new sword? No need for an alchemist's bench or anvils, go ahead bring up the damned crafting menu and make everything you want.

It's not really a Gothic game. It's not even a good RPG game. But if you want to get a few more Gothic like moments out of anything, this is the best option you may have.
